div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: NOTICE.
div.p: Ahmad Bey Neguib El-Gawahergi, Jeweller, herewith begs to inform all merchants that he had made a contract with Ismail Effendi Kamel for the business to be done in the establishment, which was opened in the mouski, but as the latter did not comply with the rules of commerce and the contract, it was found necessary to make a liquidation by stocktaking of the said establishment.
If any merchant has a claim or a debt against the firm, I am ready to pay him according to the agreement made, if his right be proved.
Merchants will have to send in schedules of their accounts from this date.31610-3-1

div.head: THE OXYRHYNCHUS FINDS.
div.p: No discoveries in the literature of antiquity have an interest so intimate and so wide as those which throw new light upon the person and the work of Christ. Two years ago in the mounds of Oxyrhynchus in the Fayoum, which have already yielded as the "Logia," the "Sayings," of Jesus, there was found a single small vellum leaf, somewhat torn at the corpers, on which a scribe had contrived to write some forty-five lines. They proved to be an account of conversations between Christ and His disciples and Christ and a certain chief priest, of which we have no other record. The script is apparently of the fourth century. This fragment of a new gospel has now been made socessible in an excellent edition prepared by Dr. Grenfell and Dr Hunt. It opens in the middle of a sentence which is part of a speech of Jesus to His disciples, affirming that the penalty of sin is not complete here, but that "the evildoers among men await punishment and much torment" hereafter. The word translated "torment" is "basanoss," which has elsewhere been emphasised by ingenious people anxious to explain the traditional torment of hell as a testing or a trial. From this the fragment proceeds to conversation between Jesus and "a certain Pharisee, a chief priest," whose name is not certainly legible concerning the value of ceremonial purity. The chief priest complains that Christ has looked on the holy vessels unwashed and defiled, has walked in the temple "which is a pure place." He proceeds to give a curious description of his own ablutions: "For I washed in the pool of David, and having descended by one staircase I ascended by ano ther," and so on. There comes a vebement and somewhat rhetorical reply. "Thou hast washed in these running waters wherein dogs and swine have been cast night and day, and bast cleansed and wiped the outside skin. ... Bat I and my disciples, who, thou sayest bave not batbed have been bathed in the waters of everlasting life...." Then with the words, "But woe unto thee ..." the fragment breaks off. It will be obvious that the episode has its parallels in the canonical gospels, and that its spirit is entirely in scoord with all that we know of Christ's teaching. The fact that Christ is throughout referred to only as "Soter," "Saviour," after the manner of the Gpostios, is the only ground for imputing anything onorthodox But to accept the narrative as a plain record of fact is difficult. There is no reason to believe that a Jew had to wash and change his clothes when visiting the temple. It is almost impossible to believe that a chief priest would bathe in a pool into which dead dogs and swine were cast. The "Pool of David" is unknown to us from any other writing, and the two stairways, one for the dirty and one for the clean, have all the air of things of the imagination. All this, however, is not to say that the fragment is entirely unhistorical. It seems to us plainly an instance of the literary elaboration of a tradition. Some writer--and a writer of skill, for he uses an attractive style and a number of unworn words-bas worked over old stories. His date was probably in the latter half of the second century, and his dwelling. place Egypt No competent judge is likely to dispute the conclusion of Dr. Grenfell and Dr. Hunt that "the fragment is an interesting and valuable addition to the scanty remnant of the numerous uncanonical traditions concerning Christ's teaching which were current in many Christian communities, especially in Egypt, during the third and fourth centurion."

div.head: Railways to Mecca.
div.p: The Sultan, in order to provide greater facilities for Mohamedans desiring to make the pilgrimage to Mecca, has given orders for the construction of a new railway from Mecca to Arafat and for the completion of the line from Medina to Mecca, a distance of 280 miles, before the next pilgrimage takes place

div.head: English Grammar for Egyptians.
div.p: Mr. Hussein Rouhy, professor of English in Mustapha Kamel's school is the author of two serviceable elementary works on the English language, a first forin grammar and analysis, and a thousand and one grammar questions and answers These are very practical bandbooks and should be useful to beginners in English

div.head: Books to Get
div.p: "Who's Who for 1908" (Adam and Charles Black) becomes bulkier and more indispensable every year. The biographies of well-known Anglo-Egyptians are excellent and very up to date "Who's Who Year Book for 1908" and the "Writers and Artistes Year Book for 1908," issued by the same publishers, are replete with most concise and useful information

div.head: Boulac Bridge Contracts.
div.p: The tenders for the construction of a bridge across the Nile at Boulac were opened yesterday morning at the Ministry of Public Works. The following is a list of the tenders: Fives Lille. LE 298,681 ; Schneider LE. 401,803 ; Cochrane and Sons, LE 350,675; Payde et Pille, L. E. 360,000 ; Cleveland, L.E282,497 ; Arrol, L, E. 465,665. As it may be seen from the list the lowest tender is that of Messrs. Cleveland. The commission charged with the examination of the tenders will probably not give its opinion before at least two months.

div.head: "The Sudanese Red Sea."
div.p: What exactly is the "Sudanese Red Sea" w do not know, but most likely the term embraces the Sudanese coast of the Red Sea. In the official report of the Linnean Society, held in London on the 5th inst, the following re. ports were read :-"Report on the Alcyonaria of the Sudanese Red Sea,' by Prof. J. A. Thomson, and Mi. J. M. McQueen,- Report on the Crinoidea of the Sudanese Red Sea,' by Mr. H. C Chadwick, -'Notes on some Marine Aluse from the Red Sea,' by Prof. R. J Harvey Gibson,--and Report on the Hydroids of the Sudanese Red Sea,' by Miss L Roscoe Thornely

div.head: A Trip to Sinai
div.p: Mr. Papamichailopoulo, the late Heller Minister of Education, left Suez hy vestering morning's train for Port Said, where he will have a very short stay, and then pred for it few days to Cairo. The ex-Minister seeint quite enthusiastic with his recent studies at Mount Sinai, which will enable him to finish very abortly the book, which he had commenced three years ago. He ascended last week the highest point of St. Catherine, which is 2,602 metres above the sea level, and at the time Snow was heavily talling on the mountain, and the temperature was below zero.

div.head:
CHRISTMAS IN ALEXANDRIA
AT THE BLIND SCHOOL.
div.p: (FROM CORRESPONDENTS.)

Christmas day was, no doubt, very much enjoyed by many people in Alexandria, but one may safely say by none so much as by the Alumni of the industrial school for the blind in Sheikh Aly el Lessi street. Thanks to the kind thonght of the manager of this institute, Mr. J. Tongs, and of his benevolent and Christian-spirited wife, who bad solicited the contributions of a few generous people, a splendid dinner was provided for the blind boys, amongst whom are to be found Mohamedans, Jews and Copts, and a very happy day was spent by them. After a genuine English dinner, consisting of the traditional turkeys, roast beef and plum. pudding, the blind boys prolonged their festive meeting around their bright and jovial tables for a good part of the afternoon, partaking of the variety of fruit, with which their table, were loaded, indulging in merry chat and occasional songs, and thus forgetting tbeir dismal lot. The parental solicitude of Mr. and Mrs. Tongs for the welfare and all possible happiness of the unfortunate blind boys is worthy of all praise. But this highly useful and philanthropic establishment does not unfortunately seem to be es well-known as it ought to be to the people of Alexandria, and especially to the wealthy, who would be sure to come forward and give it that material support which it so much needs and so well deserves, if its obvious usefulness or even its existence were to come to their knowledge, The Industrial School for the Blind has for its object, primarily, to teach the boys an industry, and as such basket and chair-making has been cbosen, which is the case in similar institutions in other countries, and in the second place, to teach the blind boys reading and writing according to the Braille system. Owing to the assiduous devotion of Mr. and Mrs. Tongs considerable progress has been made, within a few months, in both these objects. But in spite of the usefulness of the institution, its means are so limited, that its beneficial intluence is very limited, confined of necessity to only a few blind boys. Were its means ampler, a larger number of blind boys would be accomodated within its philan thropic walls, and thus a greater number of sadly suffering tellow creatures would have been taught a useful industry whereby to earn their livilihood, and would have been made happier We many add that this institution was projected by Lady Meath, who greatly helped in its crention and contributes to its maintenance
ST. ANDREW'S CHURCH.

A special service was held in St. Andrews Church, Alexandria, on Christinas morning, when the Rev. Hugh P. Reid, the Minister officiated. The church was beautifully decorated with palin branches, evergreens, plants and flowers. Among those who sent the contribu tions were Mrs. Lang Anderson, Mrs. J. Davies Bryan, Mrs. E Jones, Mrs. Mucha Orel, Mrs. Tulloch and Miss Russell Assistance in de coration was kindly given by Mrs. Chorlia, Mr. and Mrs Thum, Misses Gibson, Coutts, Russell, and the Misses Webb. The usual Christmas hymus were sung and the sermon was preached from the text in Isaiah:- A virgin shall bear a sun and shall call his name Immanuel"
THE WESLEYAN CHURCH,

Christmas day services were conducted at Mustapha and at the Sailors and Soldiers' In: stitute at Alexandria by the Rev. W. Dickins, Miss Wood presided at the organ and Miss Emerson accompanied with the violin. The service opened with the grand old anthem "How beantiful upon the mountains." The old favourite hymn was sung with great heartiness, and the address einpbazised the unique personality and influence of Christ as acknowleged by the world way. The ordi nary congregation is largely increased by the pirer of the 11 from HMS "Diana" now in port. Later in the day a delightful time was pent at the Chaplin's bouse when some of thie Ist elements of military navel and civil life must bappily and humourously blended.
KOM EL DIK.

The Christmas festivities of the Military Police Corps were carried ont at kom el Dik in an admirable manner, under a most ener getic and hard working committee Great praise is due Sergt. F. Howard of the Corps, who personally conducted the whole affairs, with excellent results The Commanding Officer, Lieut. A. B. Wakelin, Army Service Corps, visited Kom el Dik about 1 pm. to drink the health of all the Military Police, this being done with musical benoury. Afterwards three cheers were given for him, which could have been beard at some considerable distance. A splendid dinner was then served, needless to say, justice being done to it. The next important item of the day was the smoking con cert, which commenced about 8 pm. and was a marked success. Sergt f Howard took the chair, and presided over a large audience, consisting of civilian, naval and military people. Sougs, dances, etc., were given in galore, and special laention must be made of the representatives of HMS "Diana" who contributed some very good songs, to the amusement of all prenent At midnight, the whole proceedings of the day 26th December, 1907) were over, on sing. ing the grand old National Anthem "God' save the King." Sergt. T. Fayers, Army Service Corps, accompanied the songs at the piano, provided for the purpose.
KASR EL NIL, CAIRO

The officers of the King's Royal Rifles gave their annual tea and Christmas Tree to the married families of the Battalion in the recreation room at Kasr el Nil barracks Cairo last evening. A large number sat down to tea after which the children received presents off the tree from the hands of Mrs. Markbam, while the married ladies received articles of Cseful clothing, the gift of the Needlework Guild.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE
div.p: The Khedive attended midday prayers today at the Said Nafisa Mosque, Cairo. After the Courban Beiram the Khedive will inagurate the Mohamed Ali School at Alexandria and lay the foundatian stone of Asile Abbas adjoining the school.

div.head: THE LATE REV. D. P. MILLER
div.p: Amidst manifestations of sorrow and deep sympathy, the remains of the late Reverend David Proctor Miller, M.A., Chaplain to the Forces, Citadel, Cairo, were laid to rest in the new cemetery with military bonours. The coffin, which was draped with the Union Jack, was borne from the Citadel on a gun carriage driven by sergeants of the Royal Horse Artillery. At Old Cairo, the procession was joined by a large number of officers and, preceded by the bands of the King's Own Soottish Borderers and King's Royal Rifles, wended its way to the new cemetery. The scene at the graveside was very impressive. The burial service was read by the Rev. Armitage S.C F. and the Rev Anderson C.P., the other robed clergy present being the Rev. J. Hilton Moles. worth M.A. and the Rev J. F. Burns M. A. of All Saints, the Rev. Gardner, the Rev. Thomas and the Rev McInnes. Following the blessiug. the firing party fired three volleys over the grave and the pipers of the K.OS.B. played a Dead March and finally the band played "Peace Perfect Peace". Amongst those present at the graveside were Major General Bullock, C.B., Colonel Cuthbert, Major Knight, Colonel McFarlane, Owen Bey, Herbert Bey, Watson Pagba and British officers of the Egyptian Army., Major Hardy and officers RAM.C., officers Royal Artillery, Captain Duffus, A S.C. Dr. Madden and a large number of civilians. Many beautiful wreaths were sent by the Chaplains, Major General, Mrs. and Miss Bullock, Officers K.O.S.B., Matron and nurs. ing sisters of the Military Hospital, Rev. and Mrs. Jeffray, British Officers of the Egyptian Army, Major and Mrs. Knight, Major and Mrs. Stevenson, Captain and Mrs. Darrell, Mr. and Mrs. Appleton. Mr. Miller, who was but 35 years of age studied at St. Andrews, and came to Cairo last May from Shropshire.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA HARBOUR
div.p: THE GREAT PASS.

The new Great Page will be opened on the 30th inst. The ceremony will begin at 2.30 p.m. Rear Admiral Sir Massie Blomfield will sever his connection with the service of the Egyptian Government on the following day. 'The extension of the quay immediately to the West of the Mahmoudieh locks (known as Quay E) will very shortly be taken in hand. The work will be commenced from the outer end. The general direction of the prejected ex. tension lies N. 34 W. from the centre of the quay, length to be 1500 feet, and breadth 300 feet. Four buoys will be laid down to mark the area in which material will be deposited, and mariners should not take their vessels inside the lines of buoys.

div.head: QUARANTINE TUG
div.p: A 40 feet steam tug has just been completed by Messrs. Ashton and Kilner of Poole, Eng land, for the Egyptian Government to be used in the Quarantine Service. She is construct ed of teak throughout, and her lines are very much admired. She is fitted with 45 I H.P. compound surface condensing engines of the most modern type This tug bas just been shipped to Egypt by Messrs. Willians and Geils, the transport ngents of London, and who for the last 40 years and more have been associated with the shipment of heavy launches and machinery and plant to various parts of Egypt. The litting weight all told) of this tug was close upon 11 tons, but this is not looked upon As formidable as they have in hand a 25 ton package of machinery for Egypt which is a somewhat exceptional weight.

div.head: THE REFORM PARTY
div.p: A general meeting of the Reform Party was held on Wednesday last, which was attended by Prince Mohamed Aly Halim Pasha. Sheikh Aly Youssef made a speech on the objects of the new Party. He alluded most sympathetically to the loss Egypt had sustained by the death of the leader of the Party of the People. Mohamed Bey Said and Hafez Effendi Awad afterwards delivered some speeches and the meeting closed. The speech of Sheikh Aly Youssef occupies columns and columns of yesterday's issue of "Al Moayad." He declared that the object of the new Party was not to oppose, but to show the Government the needs of the people of Egypt. As to the British Occupation he said the Party would trust to its promises as to the eventual evacuation of the country and his arguments and quotations from English statesmen's speeches fill five columns of print. Hafiz Effendi Awad declared that the new Party was the object of the sympathy of many Radicals in the House of Commons, such as Mr. Robertson, Dr. Rutherford, etc. He stated that Dr. Rutherford would be in Egypt next month and that the Party would entertain him to a banquet. Owing to the support the Party was receiving from people in England, it would be the first among all the political parties in Egypt. It is announced that some Coptic notables of Cairo have given their adherence to the party.

div.head: THE REPUBLICAN PARTY
div.p: We have received a lengthy manifesto, written in French, from the leader of the Republican Nationalist Party, Mohamed Ganem of Cairo. He writes La nouvelle de la constitution d'un Parti Républicain a été favorablement accueillie par l'opinion publique surtout à la suite de l'article précédemment inséré dans votre journal on nous avons défini la marche à suivre conformément aux principes républicains qu'il faudrait donner à ce parti pour lui faciliter l'intui. tion des idées républicaines dans le peuple. La devise de ce parti sera: L'Egypte doit être une République. Toute souveraineté dans la vallée du Nill doit émaner de la Nation." Je dois me réjouir que l'appel que j'ai fait à la Nation dans votre journal n'a pas été sans écho et la presse arabe libérale s'est empressée de me tendre courageusement la main voyant dans cet appel le cri d'un patriotisme sain et équitable reposant sur la souveraineté du peuple. Aussi beaucoup de véritables patriotes viennent de se ranger de mon côté m'invitant par leurs soins à mettre en exécution le plan du Parti The statutes of this new party are being compiled by an executive committee and will be shortly published and submitted to the approbation of the Egyptian public According to Mohamed Ganem the "raison d'être" of the party is the fear that, if the occupation be brought to an end, the country will relapse into a condition similar to what was the case in the Mamaluke era and that the only solution is the education of the people in republican principles.

div.head: KHARTOUM LAND MARKET
div.p: We hear, says the "Sudan Times," that a number of plots of building land which have not been built upon in conformity with the regulations will be forfeited on the first of January if the Government insists upon the strict execution of the regnlations. It is feared by those interested in building and agricultural lands that if this should take place, the result will be a complete paralysis of the land market, and it is hoped that the Government, taking into con sideration the financial conditions which have prevailed for several months, will extend the period during which building should be done until the present crisis is tided over.

div.head: THE GUM HARVEST.
div.p: Further arrivals of gum are reported from Dueim. Prices have fallen below the figures we quoted # bort while ago The fall is attributed either to the anticipation of a large crop this season, or to the scarcity of funds in the hands of purchasers, on account of the financial crisis now prevailing We do not believe, bowever, that the conditions of this season's crops are already sufficiently known to de terinine what the prices will be

div.head: THE NEW BRIDGES
KHARTOUM AND CAIRO
div.p: A definite announcement has just recently been made on the scheme for the establishment of a bridge over the Blue Nile at Khar tonm, incidentally required in connection with south ward extensions of the Sudan Government railway system, but primarily in con nection with Sir William Garstin's project for the irrigation of the Gbezireh, the district lying between the Blue and White Niles. The work at Khartoum which constitutes the most valuable bridge contract ever placed for any part of the African continent, will be carried out by the Cleveland Bridge and Enginneering Company (Limited), of Darlington, the same firm who completed, in September 1905, the railway bridge over the Victoria Falls of the Zambesi, an undertaking which they carried tbrongh with an expedition pro voking well deserved praise from those associated with that enterprise. For the con struction of the new bridges over the Nile re quired by the Egyptian Government to connect Bulac, the industrial quarter of Cairo, with Embabeh, the Cleveland Bridge Com. | pany's name appears amongst the list of com petitors. Their design has been worked out by Mr. G. A. Hobson (or Sir Douglas Fox and Partners) who also designed the bridge over the Za in besi.

div.head: MAPS OF EGYPT
div.p: A few days ago we published a letter from a correspondent, signed "Mercator" on the need for a general map of Egypt. Several of the questions asked by our correspondent are readily answered, though, as he says, it may not always be easy for the general public to arrive At them. This in effect was the reason for proposing a Map Exhibition. The difficulty of publishing a complete map of Egypt has been due to the fact that until there was a reliable chain of triangulation tbrough the country, it was impossible to co-ordinate the various maps any more successfully than had hitherto been dore. The urgent necessity for reassessing the Land Tax demanded the publication of Cadastral Mape first of all. The line of triangulation from Wa'i Halfa to the sea was completed about tw years ago, but the reduction of some 20,000 (audastral Maps, and the compilation of many hundreds of Desert Surveys, requires a considerable time. Half of Egypt is already published on the scale of 1:50,000 suitable for adminis' rative purposes. Maps of 1:250,000 and 1: 1,000,000 are now in band, so that the need for a general map of the country will soon be met Specimens of all these maps will be on view in the Map Exhibition which will be open to the public from the 9th to the 18th of January at the Geological Museum in Cairo.

The Cataract and Savoy Hotels had both large parties for Christmas. When the "Egypt" sailed for Luxor on her return trip yesterday she left behind quite a number of her passengers. Mr. and Mrs. Adam Frost and Mr. and Mrs. Bates left the ship for the Cataract Hotel where they stay till the 30th and then proceed to Wady Halta. Dr. Alfred Lappenburg with bis niece Miss Dorothea von Rosen from Copenhagen went to the Savoy as well as Fran Dr. M. Mayes and Mr. J. N Finney and his party who all intend staying a considerable time at Assouan. The "Egypt" was on show from 3 to 5 each day of her stay at Assouan and a great many visitors from the hotels went over the new boat and had tea on board. The first dance of the season took place at the Cataract Hotel on the 22nd Judge Dorn of San Francisco with Mrs. Dorn and Miss Elisabeth Sullivan and Miss C. Baldwin were among those of the "Egypt" passengers who were present as also Mr Ruddock Jnr. and Miss N. M Ruddock. The Earl and Countess of Rothes with their party consisting of Capt. A. H. Devenish and Lady Mildred Leslie are expected at the Cataract Hotel ou December 28th and will stop a few days on their way to the Sudan The Duke and Duchess of Devonshire are still here on their dababieh moored by Elephantine Island and seem likely to prolong their stay. A gymkhana was arranged for Christmas day in the grounds of the Cataract Hotel and there were many entries of both ladies and gentlemen for the various events. Donkey polo was a feature.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Prince Demidoff, a youthful scion of the great Russian princely family, who has been staying at Khartoum for some little time, has left for the South upon a long and arduous hunting expedition, the details of which have been conceived upon a very luxurious but im practicable scale. The young Prince, wbo is twenty-three years of age, is accompanied by his medical adviser, his chef, and a Fides Achates whose principal duties are to operate a fully equipped cinematograph apparatus, destined to faithfully portray the whole of the Prince's movements, especially when lionshooting

A perfect arsenal of lethal weapons accompanies this strange party, while several large steel gins, or traps, for the lions and many weird implements for capturing and skinning hippopotami, rhinoceri, and crocodiles are included. No tewer than seventy-five small Abyssinian and Sudanese donkeys accompany the expedition, as well as three small English fox-terriers, which will never live to see the land of their birth again. A private steamer has been secured, at a cost of about £25 a day, the fuel bill alone being responsible for something like £7 daily. The party of hunters expect to be away for six or seven months, and to make their way into the French Congo, I probably coming out on the West coast of Africa
The Earl and Countess of Cromer are spend ing Christmas at Ardgowan, Greenock, with Sir Hugh and Lady Alice Shaw-Stewart.

The Earl of Cromer was recently invited by the Glasgow and West of Scotland Unionist Free Trade Club to attend a luncheon on Friday, Jan. 10. He has now accepted the invita tion, and will deliver a short address. Other | prominent Unionist Free Traders are expected. to be present and take part in the proceedings.
Sir Eldon Gorst has left for the Sudan to meet Mr. Winston Churchill.
Mrs. Gedge will in future be "at bome" on Mondays instead of Tuesdays as before.

Sir Thomas Lipton, who arrived by the S.S. "Heliopolis" at Alexandria on Tuesday night, tayed at the Savoy Palace Hotel for Christmas and left for Cairo yesterday aftervoon where he will stay at the Savoy Hotel. His stay in Egypt will be of brief duration for he is embarking for Ceylon on Tuesday next, where he bas large interests. Sir Thomas will probably make a short stay in Egypt on his way back in six weeks time.

The Marquis of Anglesey, Colonel and Lady Blanche Smith, Lord Eustace Cecil, Major Erskine, Mr P. Rom, and Mr. and Mrs. Clement Shorter, were among the departures from Alexandria yesterday by the S.S. "Heliopolis." Sir John Aird is lying ill at Wilton Park, Beaconsfield, having had a relapse. Sir Robert Pullar, M. P., who is staying at the Cataract Hotel, Assouan, is one of the proprietors of the well-known dye works at Perth, where his father reigned for six years as Lord Provost of the city. Sir Robert Pullar is chairman of the Eastern Committee of the Scottish Liberal Association, and president of the Perth Liberal Club and Association. Mrs. Irene Harvey (Irene Osgood)ot Guilsborough Hall, Northampton, who came to Egypt on the "Heliopolis," on her maiden voyage, bas taken a suite of rooms for the winter in the new buildings of the Al Hayat Hotel at Helouan. She has already derived benefit from the desert air and the onlphur baths and has energetically set to work on ber new novel, the opening scenes of which are laid in Cairo, Alexandria and Helonan. Mrs. Harvey is delighted with the quality of the Arab ponies which are to be found here and her groom, Mason, who accompanied her from Gailsborough with other servants is getting several for her. It will be news to the many friends in Egypt of Sir Rennell Rodd that the erstwhile 1st Secretary at the British Agency at Cairo once collaborated with Oscar Wilde in a work entitled "Rose Leaf and Apple Leaf," por is this fact chronicled in the list of Sir Rennell Rodd's literary efforts given in "Who's Who." We only, however, know of one Rennell Rodd, and an advertisement in the "Atheneum" of the 21st inst. runs as follows: Oscar Wilde Wanted, Rose Leat and apple leaf by Oscar Wilde and Rennell Rodd, Pbiladelphia, 1882. Printed on parchment interleaved with green tissue. Good price given for nice copy-Collector, Box 1320. Atbenæum Press, 18, Bream's Buildings, Chancery Lane E C. Sir Rennell Rodd gained the "Newdigate" in 1880 and in 1188 entered the Diplomatic Bervice. Oscar Wilde won the same prize in 1878.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Vendredi 27 Décembre)

Comme on pouvait s'y attendre à l'occasion des fêtes et en sympathie avec la situation générale, les affaires se sont encore raréfiées sur notre place. La tendance est excessivement lourde, les vendenrs qui affluent plus que ja mais ne trouvant pas de contre partie. On se fera une idée de la pauvreté des transactions en observant qu'on offre des titres d'une fraction de livre par 400 5, alors qu'à l'époque de l'activité les courtiers recevaient avec pitié des ordres de 25. Encore ne peut on vendre qu'avec de telles difficultés que l'épargne à cours d'argent pour ses échéances liquide ses obligations Crédit Foncier a des prix déri 01 s. C'est en effet la seule valeur ou à peu près qui trouve acquéreur. A part cela, rien d'intéressant à signaler pour la séance de ce matin qui, comme nous venons de le dire, a été plus morne encore que d'habitude, sinon one reprise inattendue vers cloture en Ritz Hotels, sur la nouvelle que l'affaire Bacos serait en bonne voie d'arrangement. Dans ces conditions on peut s'étonner du zèle que mettent les agents à confectionner une cote qui n'a par le fait qu'une importance toute relative, la plupart des cours étant forcément nominaux faute de transactions. L'Agricole fléchit de 73 4 8 7 23 32 et la Ramleh de 4 3 16 à 41 8. La Delta Light s'ins. crit à 9 1/2 ex-coupon. Quant à l'Obligation ancienne Crédit Foncier, elle s'écroule de 274 å 271 1/2. On a beau dire qu'il s'agit simplement de ventes forcées d'on titre facilement négociable, certains détenteurs commencent à s'in quiéter de cette dégringolade ininterrompue, surtout que les Lots Turcs à peu près dans la même situation gagnent du terrain et s'avancent aujourd'hui de 163 à 165. En baisse également la Land Bank de 7 1 8 à 71/16, l'Urbaine de 2 7/8 à 2 13 16, le Comptoir de 2 1/8 à 2, et l'action Allotment de 2 à 1 15/16 La Banque d'Athènes reprend, au contraire, de 112 à 112 1/4 et la Banque d'Orient de 111 1/2 à 112 Les Ritz Hotels dont nous avons parlé pro gressent de 1/4 à 3/8, prix auquel il s'est traité plusieurs milliers. "Il n'y a pas de changement à signaler sur le reste de la cote. Ceux que nous venons de mentionner n'ont d'ailleurs que pen de signi fication étant pour la plupart inscrits en cloture sur la demande de quelques intéressés. Demain la corbeille des valeurs étant fermée, notre prochain bulletin ne paraitra que lundi 30 courant.

Il y a eu plusieurs ventes de la part du commerce aussi bien que de la spéculation. Il y a eu de fortes ventes en coton Mai de la part du commerce GRAINES DE COTON Le marché a ouvert à 72 34 acheteurs le Février Mars. On a pratiqué le prix de P.T. 73; vers les onze heures le marché de Minet elBassal a commencé à vendre et on a fléchi jus. qu'à 72 1/4. En clôture on était acheteurs à 72 1/4 et vendeurs à 72 15 40. L'Avril a été peu traité ce matin ; le prix est de 74 vendeurs.

div.head: Credit Fonoler Egyptien
div.p: Messieurs les Actionnaires sont convoqués a l'Assemblée Générale Ordinaire qui aura lieu le Vendredi 31 Janvier 1908 à 3 heures de l'après-midi au Siège Social au Caire. ORDRE DU JOU'RE 1 Lecture du Rapport du Conseil d'Admi nistration sur les affaires sociales 2. Lecture du Rapport des Censeurs 3'. Approbation des comptes et fixation du dividende pour l exercice 1907 4'. Voinination d'Administrateurs ; 5o. Nomination de deux Censeurs pour l'e xercice 1908. Tout porteur de 50 actions a le droit d'assister à l'Assemblée Générale et conformément à l'article 28 des statuts, les actions devront être déposées : En Egypte : au plus tard le 30 Janvier 1908. En Europe : au plus tard le 20 Janvier 1908. Les dépôts seront reçus : au Caire : au Siège social ; à Alexandrie: au Crédit Lyonnais ; à la Banque de Paris et des Pays-Bas, au Crédit Lyonnais, à la Société Générale pour fa voriser le développement du en Europe Commerce et de l'Industrie en France, an Comptoir Vational d'Es. compte, à la Société Générale de Crédit Ind. & Commercial.

div.head:
THE MOROCCAN SITUATION.
GENERAL DRUDE ILL.

div.p: Colonel Routegourd is replacing General Drude at Casablanca, the latter being seriously (Havas)
General Lyautey has returned to Marnia. The tribes are continuing to surrender. (Ravas)
Peace is restored at Fez The authorities have decided not to exact the payment of taxes. (Havas)

As the result of an interview between M. Regnault and the Sultan, General Drude has been instructed to drive out the rebels from their fortress in the Mediuna country, the possession of which is an obstacle to the pavification of the Chawias and the restoration of Casablanca to the Moorisb authorities. Reconnaissances encountered the enemy's cavalry in force (Reuter)
General Drude is seriously ill with malaria. Colonel Boutegard has assumed command at Casablanca. (Reuter)

div.head:
ROW IN A CATHEDRAL
AN UNEMPLOYED'S PROTEST,

div.p: During the Christmas morning service in the Catbedral a leader of the unemployed entered the pulpit and attempted to address the congregation. He was ejected after a violent struggle. (Renter)
A runaway electic car descending Penton ville Hill collided with a car at King's Cro-8. Eight persons were injured. (Reuter)
A gale occurred on Christmas eve which resulted in several shipwrecks. Passengers between Liverpool and the Isle of Man spent the night at sea and only landed late yesterday (Reuter)
The Kaiser, who is going with the Empress to Corfu, will confer with King George (Havas)
Baroness Adolph Rothschild has bequeathed £400,000 to charities and Jewish institutions, to the benefit largely of Paris institutions. (Reuter)
Five more naval mutineers here have been sentenced to be shot. (Reuter)
Troops have been stationed on the Finnish frontier to control the passage of travellers.
The Empress Eugenie has started for Exipt via Marseilles. (Reuter)

div.head: PROPOSED MEMORIAL IN EGYPT.
div.p: TO THE LATE REV. DM. THORNTON
The following letter, signed by the Bishop of Durham, Mr. T.F. Victor Buxton, Mr. J.B. Braddon, and Mr. T. W. H. Inskip has been pent to the Press :

"It will be within the recollection of many of your readers that at the beginning of September last the Church of England lost one of the ablest of her younger missionaries by the death of the Rev. D. M. Thornton, of the Church Missionary Society's mission in Cairo. It is strongly felt by us and others of his friends that so remarkable a personality as his, conspicuous as it was for unconquerable energy and untiring devotiou, should not be lett without some permanent memorial in the land to which he gave his lite. We bave accordingly decided to open a Douglas Thornton Memorial Fund to be placed in the bands of trustees for the furtberance of his plans for the extension of Christ's kingdom in Egypt. One of his greatest ambitions, to the attainment of which he himself contributed in no small measure, was the circulation in Egypt of wholesome Christian literature, chiefly in Arabic. We have reason to know that the insufficiency of funds to carry out his plans in this direction was a constant burden to him, and that projects of great importance and usefulness were thus frequently hampered. He was always a profound believer in the power of the printed page to advance Christ's kingdom among men. We are assured by those who know that no scheme would be of greater assistance to the mission than this, or more immediately fruitful in strengthening the cause which he loved. Nor would it be easy to name one which would do more to keep his memory alive, for every book or pamphlet would bear his name. If sufficient funds are available we might turn our attention to some of the other projects which Mr. Thornton had so much at heart. We therefore confidently appeal to all his friends and to all who profited by his word and example to give us their warm support. The fund will be administered by a committee consisting of the following : --The Bishop of Durham, the Maxter of Trinity, Archdeacon Pelham, Rev. R. Melones (Cairo), Rev. W.HT. Gairduer (Cairo), Rev. G. T. Manley, Rev. Theodore Woods, Rev. Tissington 'Tatlow, Rev. J.H. Oldhain, Mr. T. F. V. Buxton, Mr. Eliot Howard, Mr. G. A King, Mr. Eugene Stock, Mr. J. B. Braddon, and Dr. C. F Harford. Donations may be sent to Mr. TWH luskip, treasurer of the fund, at the Church Missionary Honge, Salisbury-square, EC, or to Messrs. Henry S. King and Co. bankers, 9, Pall-mall, S. W., for credit of the "Douglas Thornton Me. morial Fund."

div.head: ACTIVE SERVICE POCKET BOOKS
div.p: We have received a copy of the third and enlarged edition of Lieut. Bertrand Stewart's "Active Service Pocket Book," which has been called for by the rapid sales of the first and second editions, not only at home, but in India and throughout the colonies. The book has been increased from 125 pages to 932 pages, contains 156 pilates, and is only about one inch thick, being printed on Oxford India paper. A large number of important new subjects bave been dealt with and this convenient manual bas in fact become indispensable to every sol dier. The publishers are Wmn Clowes & Sons, London

div.head: MONEY AND SHARE MARKET.
div.p: The Money Market.

The redemption of £4,000,000 Argentine Treasury Bills which fell due last Monday caused considerable displacements of cash, and the result of this movement was to create a better enquiry for short loans at rates ranging fron 4 to 5 per cent. When it became known later on in the same day that New York had bought nearly all the bar gold in the market (about £500,000)the demand for loans increased still further, and three months bills were quoted at 54 per cent. The Bank rate remains at 7 per cent, although it was suggested earlier in the week that it might be lowered, but the present rate has been maintained as a protective measure against Germany, a monetary stringency being expected in Berlin at tbe end of the year, and it is thought that the Reicbsbank will have to raise its rate. The Bank return for the week ending December 18th shows that considerable inroads were made on the Bank reserve by the bomo demand for currency. The withdrawal of gold however was off set by the release of sovereigns by the India Council, but £1,213,000 in coin and £188,000 notes were taken into circulation and the reserve bas declined by £1,275,000, while the percentage to liabilities is 1 per cent lower The comparison with last year shows the Bank reserve to be to-day £22,399,000 as against £19,712,000 and the proportion of cash to liabilities 45.90 per cent as against 887 per cent last year. The application for the £2,500,000 of Treasury Bills at six months reached a total £5,803,000. Tenders at £98 received about 97 per cent of the amount applied for. The average rate of discount being, 83, 198 110.97 as against £3, 138. 1.6d at which the previous allotment of similar bills was made. This should therefore prove satisfactory to the Government in view of the fact that the Bank rate at the time of the earlier issue viz 23 September last was only 5 per cent., as compared with 7 per cent. now
Silver.

There was a sharp rally in Silver yesterday, the covering of "bear operations." The week began with a decline in the price of silver owing to selling by the Indian bazaars, but some buying yesterday to cover "bear operations caused a sbarp rally and the price was marked up to 25 tad per ounce for im mediate delivery and 25 d for forward delivery. There were however not many purchasers at the higher figure and prices do not appear to be at all firm.
Stock Markets

With the exception of Yankees which bave shown some spirit, an entire lack of interest has been noticed in the Stock Markets during the present week; a holiday feeling has settled on every body and it is expected to remain 80 until after Christmas.
Console.

There has been practically nothing doing in Consols and prices bave been inclined to ease off. As an illustration of the state of stagnancy which exists, there were only three markings on Wednesday in the Official list in Consols, and these together did not involve more the £3,000 stock
Foreign Bonds.

A renewed enquiry for Russian Bonds was reported, and the Fives closed a up at S.S. atter touching 897. Argentine Bonds were also enquired for, the 1900 Pours rising & , but other South American issues were marked down. Japanese bonds were steady, and amongst the Chinese issues the 1906 Fived put on a half.
Home Rails

The Home Rail Market appears to be at present in a state of expectancy. Meetings of shareholders in the Great Central and Great Northern Companies to ratify the working agreement are to take place to day, and in view of this some support has been given to the issues of these Companies. Some dealings have taken place in Brighton "A" on the strength of rumours being circulated that the dividend is to be increased. It is guardedly stated that certain economies have been effected which will enable a declaration of nearer 4 per cent to be made than 3 per cent. The traffic returns of nearly all lines show increases, which in view of the disorganization of freights by the gale last week, are satisfactory.
Americans

Support was given to the American market which experienced quite a small boom. The report of the failure of two American Banks one in Pittsburg and ope in Massachusetts, instead of depressing the market, had a salutary effect and business showed an increase. Another factor which made for strength was the declaration of several of the railroad divi. dends, Readings being helped by the announce ment of the regular semi-annual dividend of 2 per cent. New York Central announced the usual quarterly dividend, but owing to the poor statement concerning the year's earnings the distribution failed to influence the stook. On Thursday Union Pacifics came in for a good deal of support and advanced from the opening fig' re of 119 to 120). Other prominent teatures in this section were Southern Pacifics and Atchisons, the former gaining it to 1204 and the latter 1 to 72. The increase in the Traffic receipts of the Canadian Pacific Rail. way of $216,000 had little effect on this stock, which, however, moved up with Yankees generally
Egyptians

The Egyptian Market has been very dull during the whole of the week, and there are far more sellers than buyers for the moment. Khedivial Mail Ordinary after being dealt in at 21/8, ex dividend of 2/- per share, have fallen away to 20/-sellers, and to day it has been impossible to get even a bid for a line of shares. Egyptian Estates are also down to 7/8, and Corporation of Western Egypt to 8/— United Egyptian Lands have ebanged at 4/9 several times, but there are heavy sellers about Aboukir Land is a firm spot at 1.7/16 , and a good number of shares have been dealt in. National Bank or Egypt are easier at 207, and Agricultural Banks likewise at H. Dairs Sanieh are called 1247, and Deterred 65-70 It seems difficult to deal in Salt and Soda, and Egyptian Markets at the present time, there being only sellers about; the nominal prices being $ and ittit respectively. Delta Preference (Bearer) have changed hands at 9 and 9.18/16 closing about this price of 9 Delta land and Investment are very dull at 1. A to Land and General Trust are also dull at a nominal.
South Africans

The declarations of dividends of a number of the gold mines has had practically no effect on the market, and business has been restricted, - The East Rand Proprietary and H.F. Com pany propose to distribute 8s 6d and 58 6d per share respectively, the Angelo 48 6d, Cason 68, Driefontein 2s and New Comet Is 8d per sbare The H.F. Company's distribution is the first announced by this undertaking, and it is accounted for by the fact that the Company now shares to the extent of 25 per cent in the available profits of the East Rand Company. This also explains the reduction in the East Rand's own dividend from 5s 6d in June to 38 6d for the curreut balf year. Simmer and Jack announces a dividend of 1s 6d per sbare, as against Is in June and 18 last December ; the Knight's Deep declares 2s, against half yearly dividends of is hitherto; and the Robinson Deep comes forward with 38 6d per share the same amount as was declared in June and December last. The London office of the De Beers Mines has received telegraphic advice from Kimberley to the effect that the results of the balf year ending December 31 are sufficient to admit of the declaration of a dividend of 20 per cent. on the Preference shares and more than that on the Deferred sbares, after making ample provision for taxation and depreciation ; but the demand for diamonds having recently fallen off considerably, the Board of Directors consider it is more prudent to declare only the Preference dividend at present and to retain their surplus cash in hand in order not to be compelled to force the sale of their production. div.head: SPORT AND PLAY
K.S.C.
div.p: POLO MATCH

Major Ansell's team versus Major Haig's team : Major Haig's team. Major Ansell's team. Capt. Oates I Mr de Calry 1. Bartlett II. Capt. Nixon II Mr. Bowen III. Major Paterson III. Major Haig (back). Ansell (back). This was a fast game, but Major Haig's team was the stronger, winning 5 goals to love, Major Haig and Mr. Bowen made some splendid long hits Mr. Bowen has bitherto been a very uncertain player, but he seems now to be improving every day. Major Ansell has not yet found his form ; when be does, the Indiskilling Dragoons will probably "take on" and defeat any other combination in Cairo. The match arranged between the Majors and Captains bad to be postponed.
HELOUAN GOLF CLUB

The first of the usual weekly competitions beld during each winter season took place on Saturday, and consisted of play against bogey. In the 18 holes Mr. II Swinson was tbe winner with 2 down. In the Ladies 9 holes Mrs. Ivigo Triggs easily won with the fine score of 3 op. The new professional J.B. Fulford recently accomplished a fine performance when playing in a three ball match with Mr. W. Brooks and Mr. G. E. Legge. He went round in 70 thus narrowly missing equalling the record professional score for the course made by his brother, Horace Fulford, last winter. When it is remembered that the bogey is 80 all players who are acquainted with the course will agree that the performances of the two brothers are exceptionally fine.

div.head: "BY THEIR FRUITS YE SHALL KNOW THEM."
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Sir,- Ooly a short time ago I bad occasion to write to you with reference to the stale new, which filled one part of a native paper, and the vapid articles which took up the front page ; you were so good as to publish my letter and this encourages me to again call your atten tion, and I hope that of your readers, to a question of wider interest which also refers to the native press of this country, and more particularly to those papers published in Arabic and consequently addressed especially to tbe native Egyptians. This press has been accorded an almost exuberant liberty, which might well be the envy of most European editors; and I suppose this has been done for some good purpose. I imagine that a paternal Government thought it migbt be the means of educating the masses of the population, but so far as I am able to judge, it bas not done much in this way. It is true that the Arabic papers are always crying out for more schools, but has it never occurred to them, that there is in this country a vast number of people too old to go to school, and yet who's ignorance on every question, except those connected with the routine of their daily life, is profound. I will refer to one question only and that is an essential one, – the contemporary history of their own country say tor the last forty years. It is most extraordinary how ignorant the average Egyptian is on this subject. I should like to see an elementary catechism prepared with reference to it, by tbe Ministry of Education, and no one should be allowed to take any part in politics or to do anything outside a handicraft, unless he could fairly well answer its questions Surely this is a matter that the native press should have taken up, and by not doing so they should incur the same blame as that awarded to the Scribes and Pharisees of this and neighbouring countries some 2000 years ago. I very much doubt if the great Mostata Pasba Kamel himself could pass the simple test I have suggested, with much credit, and I feel convinced that most of the members of the I.egislative Council could not do so; otherwise it would never have been recorded of them, as it was in your columns quite recently, that one of their tpost important decisions was to criticise the Egyptian Government with reference to their expenses in connection with the Sudan. Have these gentlemen no memory, can they not even remember the state of this country hardly twenty years ago ? If not let them read up the history of those times ; it is written in every language, except perhaps in Arabic, or if history is too long for them let them read the short epic poem written by Rudyard Kipling about that time, beginning with the lines, "Says England upto Pharoah, I will make & man of you, That can stand upon his feet and play the game." This poem refers to the training of the Egyptian Army after it disastrous defeat under Hicks Pasha at El Obeid ; and its two most important lines are "There were years they do not talk of, There were times of horrid doubt." These two lines mean volumes to those who know how to interpret them in the light of the state of this country at the time to which they refer; - they mean that above Wady Halfa there was a savage horde, wbo but for the restraint of a thin red line, bad both the wish and the power to murder or drive into the sea, the whole population of Lower Egypt The most extraordinary circumstance in this connection was the ignorance of the inhabitants, of the critical situation in which they were placed, but it was a time which will never be forgotten by those who had a clearer insight While these things were going on, the present Members of the Legislative Council were being brought up like chicks in wool, in a state of ignorance from which they seem never to have emerged. The native press may do some good if it would bring these things to their knowledge, but it would bave to be done with painfal iteration, and if these gentlemen ever get so far as to know a little of the history of their country, they may also be told that bistory otten has an uncomfortable way of repeating itself. Atter due reflection on such subjects they might be inclined to think differently of the wisdom of incurring certain expenses in con nection with the Sudan.
Truly Yours,

div.head: SUDAN MEDICAL DEPARTMENT, SUDAN.
div.p: NOTICE

The Sudan Medical Department is in need of the services of a qualified dispenser with pay commencing £16 per mensem Applications for this post will be addressed to the Director Sudan Medical Department, Khartoum They should be accompanied with all certificates, testimonials, references, etc., and with a duly filled up Application form which is obtainable (together with any information as to pay, increase of pay, conditions of service, etc.,) from the Sudan Agency, War Office, Cairo A good knowledge of English and Arabic (reading and writing) is indispensable. The chosen candidate will be taken on probation for a period of two years.

div.head: Administration des Chemins de Fer de l'Etat Egyptien
div.p: AVIS

L'Administration a l'honneur d'informer le Public, qu'une enchère publique, par voie de Kaimat Mazad sera tenue le Samedi vingt-huit Décembre courant, aux Magasins de Gabbary À Alexandrie, à neuf heures du inatin, pour la vente des vieux articles et matériaux qui se trouvent aux dits Magasins ou on peut les exminer chaque jour de neuf heures du matin à midi, les Dimanches et jours féri: exceptés, et ce conformément aux Conditions de vente et à la noinenclature relatives à ces articles et matériaux qui peuvent être consultees an bureau de Mr. le Chef du Service des Magasins Generaux à Boulac et à celui de l'Inspecteur des Magasins de Gabbary Alexandrie, Hux beures ci dessus indiquées Toute personne désirant prendre part à cette enchère devra, au préalable, verser à titre de dépôt provisoire une nomine de L E 5 Cinq Livres Egyptiennes) que l'enchérisseur declaruitjudicataire aura à parfaire jusqu'à concurrencedy 10% dix pour cent du montant de l'offre agréée et aura à enlever å ses frais les lots qui lui seront adjugés et ce dans les I lais indiqués dans la nomenclature en regard de chaque article, à compter de la date d'ac. centation de son oftre, les Dimanche et jours fériés exclus Les offres pourront etre faites sur papier timbré de trente millièmes si lintéressé ne pent pas assister aux enchères, et dans ce cas l'offre et le reçu constatant le versement du dépot provisoire seront adressés par la poste sous pli recommande à Monsieur l'Inspecteur des Magasins des (hemins de fer de l'Etat Gabbary Alexandrie et song double enveloppe, l'intérieure portant la suscription suivante "Offre pour achat de Vieux Articles et Matériaux" Toute offre faite ou déposée ultérieurement an jour et à l'heure ci-dessus désignés le sera pas prise en considération. L'Administration ne s'engage pas à accepter les prix les plus élevés ni à donner suite aux soumissions présentées. Elle se réserve le droit de diviser la vente.
Le Caire, le 14 Décembre 1907

div.head: AVIS
div.p: L'Administration des Chemins de fer de l'Etat Egyptien a l'honneur de porter à la connaissance du Public qu'elle recevra jusqu'au 5 Janvier 1908 des offres pour la fourniture, pendant un an à partir de la date de la signature du con trat, de platre du pays ('Gypse) suivant les clauses et conditions du Cabier des charges dont on peut obtenir un exemplaire au Service Central de la Voie et des Travaux au Caire, contre paiement de 100 mm Les soumissionnaires devront joindre à leur offre le reçu d'un dépôt provisoire de L.E. 15. Les offres devront être accompagnées d'une feuille de papier timbré de trente milli mes. Elles seront adressées par la poste sous pli recommandé à : M. le Directeur Général, Cheinins de fer et Télégraphes de l'Etat Le Caire. et sous double enveloppe, l'intérieure portant In suscription suivante :, "Offre pour fourniture de Platre du pays." L'Administration ne s'engage pas à accepter l'ffre la plus basse, ni à donner suite aux soumissions présentées, et elle se réserve le droit de diviser la commande. Le Caire, le 23 Décembre 1907.

div.head: Commercial & Financial Supplement of the "Egyptian Gazette. "
div.p: The Commercial and Financial Supplement of the "Egyptian Gazette" is published at midday every Saturday in time for the Austrian Lloyd's mail. The supplement contains exhaustive and important reviews of the cotton, cotton seed, and stock and share markets, with all the latest statistics up to the evening of the preceding day, complete tabular forms of the various market fluctuations, and the copies of the official telegrams of the Liverpool Cotton Association, etc., etc. Subscription for one year P.T. 100 (inclusive of postage in Egypt for abroad the postage is P.T. 10 extra). For Further particulars apply to the Manager the "Egyptian Gazette."
